node.title: France becomes latest nation to ban so-called conversion therapy
node.description: Anyone found guilty of using the scientifically discredited practice to try to change someone's sexual orientation or gender identity faces up to 3 years in jail.
node.content: ["Paris\u00a0\u2014 France has a new law that bans so-called conversion therapies and authorizes jail time and fines for practitioners who use the scientifically discredited practice to attempt to change the sexual orientation or gender identity of LGBTQ people. The National Assembly approved the new law unanimously, voting 142-0 on Tuesday evening. \u00a0 The legislation includes criminal penalties for people who are convicted of trying to \"convert\" LGBTQ people to heterosexuality or traditional gender expectations. \u00a0 The law also opens the possibility for campaigners to file civil suits on behalf of victims, an advance hailed in parliament as a breakthrough for people who hesitate or are unable to alert police themselves. \u00a0 Lawmaker Laurence Vanceunebrock, who helped steer the law's passage through parliament, said it will target \"all those who equated an identity or a sexual orientation with sickness.\" \u00a0 \"There is nothing to cure,\" she told the National Assembly.", "The French government's equalities and diversity minster, Elisabeth Moreno, described so-called conversion therapies as \"barbaric\" and told lawmakers that the suffering they inflict \"very often leaves permanent marks on bodies and minds.\" \u00a0 Under the new law, sustained efforts \"that aim to modify or reprimand sexual orientation or gender identity\" and which impact the physical or mental health of victims are punishable by up to two years in jail and 30,000 euros ($34,000) in fines. \u00a0 The punishment can increase to three years imprisonment and fines of 45,000 euros ($50,000) for attempts involving minors or other particularly vulnerable people. \u00a0 Practicing therapy to change a person's sexual orientation already is prohibited in about 20 U.S. states and the U.S. Caribbean territory of Puerto Rico. Other nations, including Canada, have adopted legislation in recent years to ban the practice. \u00a0 The French law will take effect in the next 14 days with President Emmanuel Macron's signoff. Macron hailed its passage. \u00a0 \"Let's be proud of it,\" the French leader tweeted. \"Because being oneself is not a crime.\"", "For Breaking News & Analysis Download the Free CBS News app"]
